grammars.name: Ada
grammars.description: General-purpose systems language created for the U.S. Department of Defense; emphasizes safety and reliability.
grammars.trivia: Named after Ada Lovelace; standardized first in 1983 (Ada 83) and later revisions Ada 95, 2005, 2012, 2022.

samples.description: Handwritten Ada program using vectors, records, and procedures to manage an inventory.

grammars.name: Agda
grammars.description: A dependently typed functional programming language and proof assistant.
grammars.trivia: Agda's name comes from a Swedish song about a woman named Agda who had a hen that laid eggs containing the words of the song.

samples.description: Agda standard library List module with dependent types and pattern matching.

grammars.name: Asciidoc
grammars.description: A lightweight markup language for writing technical documentation and books.
grammars.trivia: O'Reilly Media uses AsciiDoc as the source format for many of their technical books.

samples.description: AsciiDoc readme showing headers, code blocks, tables, and admonitions.

grammars.name: Assembly
grammars.description: Low-level programming language that maps mnemonic instructions directly to machine code; the earliest published example was Booth's 1947 ARC2 'Contracted Notation' assembler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathleen_Booth).
grammars.trivia: Booth detailed one of the first assemblers in her 1947 ARC report, and backward compatibility means https://archive.org/details/Intel8086ProgrammersReferenceManual.

samples.description: Exercises NASM struc/istruc directives, offsets, and data definitions.

grammars.name: AWK
grammars.description: Pattern-scanning and text processing language; original description in the 1978 paper 'AWK — A Pattern Scanning and Processing Language'.
grammars.inventor: Alfred Aho, Peter Weinberger, Brian Kernighan
grammars.trivia: Name comes from creators' initials Aho–Weinberger–Kernighan; see the https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.5555/104836 and Unix V7 manual pages for the classic implementation.

samples.description: AWK script from one-true-awk tests exercising records, fields, loops, and functions.

grammars.name: Bash
grammars.description: Unix shell and command language for GNU; see the official https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/.
grammars.trivia: Bash means 'Bourne Again SHell', a nod to the Bourne shell; Fox began coding it in January 1988 and released the first beta in June 1989 for the GNU Project (https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bash.html#Bash-History).

samples.description: doorbell.sh notifier with POSIX shell features, signals, file descriptors, and scheduling.

grammars.name: Batch
grammars.description: DOS/Windows batch scripting (.bat/.cmd); commands documented in the https://winworldpc.com/product/ms-dos/5x and modern https://learn.microsoft.com/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/windows-commands.
grammars.trivia: Batch files originated with 86-DOS/MS-DOS; Microsoft retained backward compatibility through cmd.exe—see the historical MS-DOS manuals for syntax.

samples.description: Cmder console emulator init script with argument parsing, path setup, and library calls.

grammars.name: C
grammars.description: General-purpose systems language created at Bell Labs.
grammars.trivia: C evolved from B/BCPL during 1969-1973 alongside Unix; the name comes from its predecessor B.

samples.description: Paren interpreter main with parser, eval loop, and hash table usage.

grammars.name: C#
grammars.description: Modern object-oriented language for .NET; official spec is published as https://www.ecma-international.org/publications-and-standards/standards/ecma-334/.
grammars.trivia: Originally code-named 'Cool' (C-like Object Oriented Language) inside Microsoft before being renamed C#; see the https://www.ecma-international.org/publications-and-standards/standards/ecma-334/ and early .NET announcements.

samples.description: Demonstrates ref readonly structs, in parameters, default arguments, and static refs.
Supporting struct definitions with ref readonly properties and readonly struct.

grammars.name: Caddyfile
grammars.description: Caddyfile configuration language for the Caddy web server; official docs at https://caddyserver.com/docs/caddyfile.
grammars.trivia: Caddy launched in 2015 with automatic HTTPS via Let's Encrypt; minimal syntax allows a single-line site definition—documented in the https://caddyserver.com/docs/caddyfile.

samples.description: Default Caddy distribution config showing sites, reverse proxy, and TLS settings.

grammars.name: Cap'n Proto
grammars.description: Cap'n Proto serialization and RPC system; design and spec at https://capnproto.org/.
grammars.trivia: Varda released Cap'n Proto on April 1, 2013, as a faster, zero-copy successor to Protocol Buffers; the https://capnproto.org/faq.html explains the zero-copy format.

samples.description: Cap'n Proto address book example with structs, lists, and annotations.

grammars.name: Clojure
grammars.description: Functional Lisp dialect for the JVM with strong concurrency support; official site: https://clojure.org/.
grammars.trivia: Hickey designed Clojure to simplify concurrent programming; the language was announced publicly in 2007 and documented in the https://clojure.org/releases/downloads.

samples.description: Ring middleware for parsing params and multipart requests; showcases namespaces, metadata, higher-order functions.

grammars.name: CMake
grammars.description: A cross-platform build system generator for C/C++ projects.
grammars.trivia: CMake was originally developed to support the cross-platform build needs of the Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit (ITK).

samples.description: Catch2 testing framework build configuration with options, subdirectories, and installation setup.

grammars.name: Common Lisp
grammars.description: A multi-paradigm dialect of Lisp standardized by ANSI with powerful macro capabilities.
grammars.trivia: The Common Lisp standard is over 1,000 pages long and defines nearly 1,000 symbols—making it one of the most comprehensive language specifications ever written.

samples.description: Lack web framework session middleware with closures, macros, and hash tables.

grammars.name: C++
grammars.description: General-purpose language extending C with zero-overhead abstractions; see Stroustrup's official overview at https://isocpp.org/about.
grammars.trivia: Began as 'C with Classes' in 1979 and was renamed C++ (using the C increment operator) in 1983; Stroustrup recounts the history in The Design and Evolution of C++ (https://www.stroustrup.com/dne.html).

samples.description: fmtlib chrono tests with templates, user-defined literals, chrono formatting, and GoogleTest macros.
Ark bytecode reader handling chunk parsing, endian conversion, and error cases.

grammars.name: CSS
grammars.description: Style sheet language for web documents; the living standard is maintained by the W3C (https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS/).
grammars.trivia: Wium Lie proposed CSS on 10 Oct 1994 while at CERN and it became a W3C Recommendation in 1996; see his original https://www.w3.org/People/howcome/p/Spec/ and the https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-CSS1-961217.

samples.description: Pico CSS framework with typography, form inputs, and utility selectors.

grammars.name: D
grammars.description: A systems programming language with C-like syntax, designed as a more modern alternative to C++.
grammars.trivia: Walter Bright wrote D's first compiler entirely by himself—he previously created the first native-code C++ compiler for DOS.

samples.description: Build platform detection from Dub package manager; showcases D's version conditions and compile-time metaprogramming.

grammars.name: Dart
grammars.description: Object-oriented language optimized for UI development; official site: https://dart.dev/.
grammars.trivia: Unveiled at GOTO Aarhus 2011 by Bak and Lund; the https://dart.dev/guides/language/language-tour documents its core goals, and Dart became the language behind Flutter when Google announced Flutter in 2017.

samples.description: Extension methods demo with fluent API, getters, operators, and generics.

grammars.name: Device Tree
grammars.description: Data structure for describing hardware; documented in the https://www.devicetree.org/specifications/.
grammars.trivia: Originated with Open Firmware (IEEE 1275-1994); the Flattened Device Tree format for Linux was introduced in 2005—see the https://www.devicetree.org/specifications/.

samples.description: Zephyr board DTS describing SPI, UART, regulators, GPIOs, and sensors.

grammars.name: Diff
grammars.description: Unified diff format for representing file differences; GNU diffutils manual documents the format (https://www.gnu.org/software/diffutils/manual/).
grammars.trivia: Wayne Davison proposed the unified format in Aug 1990 on comp.sources.misc; GNU diff added support in version 1.15 (Jan 1991) per the https://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=diffutils.git;a=blob;f=NEWS;hb=refs/tags/v1.15.

samples.description: Git rename refactoring patch from rpull/rpush to ssh-pull/ssh-push with docs, Makefile, and C sources.

grammars.name: Dockerfile
grammars.description: Declarative format for Docker image builds; official reference: https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/.
grammars.trivia: Introduced with Docker's first public release in 2013; the reference documents each instruction and the layer-caching model that made Docker adoption explode (https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/).

samples.description: Official Python 3.12 Docker image with GPG verification, build optimization, and multi-arch support.

grammars.name: DOT/Graphviz
grammars.description: A graph description language for defining nodes, edges, and graph layouts in Graphviz.
grammars.inventor: Stephen North and AT&T Bell Labs
grammars.trivia: Graphviz layout algorithms were developed at AT&T Labs and have been used to visualize everything from compiler internals to social networks.

samples.description: Unix family tree visualization; demonstrates creative node styling with distortion, orientation, and skew parameters.

grammars.name: DTD
grammars.description: Document Type Definition for declaring XML/SGML document structure and valid elements.
grammars.trivia: DTDs predate XML, originating from SGML in 1986. While largely superseded by XML Schema and RELAX NG, DTDs remain in use for entity declarations and are embedded in many XML documents.

samples.description: XHTML 1.0 Strict DTD defining document structure and valid elements.

grammars.name: Emacs Lisp
grammars.description: A Lisp dialect used to extend and customize the GNU Emacs text editor.
grammars.trivia: Emacs Lisp has been called 'the most widely used Lisp dialect' due to Emacs's popularity—millions of lines of Elisp packages exist.

samples.description: Emacs simple.el with defuns, defvars, and interactive commands.

grammars.name: Elixir
grammars.description: Functional, concurrent language on the BEAM VM; official site: https://elixir-lang.org/.
grammars.trivia: Valim announced Elixir in 2011 to blend Ruby-like ergonomics with Erlang's fault-tolerance; see the https://elixir-lang.org/getting-started/introduction.html and the original https://elixir-lang.org/blog/2011/01/09/introducing-elixir/.

samples.description: Phoenix controller module with plugs, alias/import/use macros, pattern matching, and response helpers.

grammars.name: Elm
grammars.description: Purely functional language for reliable web apps; see the official https://guide.elm-lang.org/.
grammars.trivia: Introduced by Czaplicki in 2012 with 'The Elm Architecture' that later inspired Redux; documented in the https://guide.elm-lang.org/architecture/ section of the guide.

samples.description: Elm SPA article page with Model-View-Update, commands, and HTML rendering.

grammars.name: Erlang
grammars.description: A concurrent, functional language designed for building fault-tolerant distributed systems.
grammars.inventor: Joe Armstrong, Robert Virding, Mike Williams
grammars.trivia: Erlang was developed at Ericsson for telecom switches—it achieved 'nine nines' (99.9999999%) uptime in production systems.

samples.description: OTP's lists module with pattern matching, guards, and list comprehensions.

grammars.name: Fish
grammars.description: A user-friendly interactive shell with syntax highlighting and autosuggestions out of the box.
grammars.trivia: Fish intentionally breaks POSIX compatibility for a cleaner syntax—its slogan is 'Finally, a command line shell for the 90s!'

samples.description: Fisher plugin manager with functions, conditionals, and command substitution.

grammars.name: F#
grammars.description: Functional-first .NET language with type inference; official docs at https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/fsharp/.
grammars.trivia: Developed at Microsoft Research and first released publicly in 2005; see Syme's early https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/fsharp/language-reference/ and the 2010 https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/fsharp/language-reference/language-specification.

samples.description: FSharp.Data HTTP utilities with modules, constants, request headers, and content types.

grammars.name: Gleam
grammars.description: Statically typed functional language for the BEAM; official docs at https://gleam.run/.
grammars.trivia: Pilfold announced Gleam in 2016 to bring ML-style typing to Erlang; version 1.0 shipped in March 2024 per the https://gleam.run/news/gleam-v1.0/.

samples.description: Gleam list operations with types, pattern matching, and tail recursion.

grammars.name: GLSL
grammars.description: OpenGL Shading Language for programmable GPUs; defined in the https://registry.khronos.org/OpenGL/specs/gl/GLSLangSpec.4.60.pdf.
grammars.trivia: Introduced with OpenGL 2.0 to replace the fixed pipeline; the Khronos/ARB spec (e.g., version 4.60) is the authoritative reference.

samples.description: Fragment shader from Vulkan samples using samplers, structs, and lighting calculations.

grammars.name: Go
grammars.description: Statically typed compiled language from Google; the canonical spec is the https://go.dev/ref/spec.
grammars.inventor: Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, Ken Thompson
grammars.trivia: Announced publicly in Nov 2009; its mascot the Gopher was created by Renée French and documented on the https://go.dev/blog/gopher.

samples.description: Gitea explore page with imports, constants, structs, and HTTP handler functions.
Gitea explore/repo handler showing routing, templating, pagination, and service calls.

grammars.name: GraphQL
grammars.description: A query language for APIs that lets clients request exactly the data they need.
grammars.trivia: GraphQL was developed internally at Facebook starting in 2012 to power the News Feed on mobile apps before being open-sourced in 2015.

samples.description: Star Wars schema from graphql-js with interfaces, types, enums, and query definitions.

grammars.name: Haskell
grammars.description: Purely functional language with lazy evaluation and strong typing; see the https://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/haskell2010/ for the language definition.
grammars.inventor: Simon Peyton Jones, Paul Hudak, Philip Wadler, et al.
grammars.trivia: Named after logician Haskell Curry; standardized in 1990 by a committee that published successive language reports—the 2010 Report remains the latest official spec.

samples.description: Cabal's Version type with pragmas, data types, typeclass instances, and bit manipulation.

grammars.name: HCL
grammars.description: HashiCorp Configuration Language for IaC; language spec lives in the Terraform docs (https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/syntax/configuration).
grammars.trivia: Designed to be both human-readable and machine-friendly; Terraform accepts both JSON and native HCL, documented in the https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language.

samples.description: Terraform VPC example using providers, modules, variables, and resource blocks.

grammars.name: HLSL
grammars.description: High-Level Shading Language for DirectX; official reference in the https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/win32/direct3dhlsl/dx-graphics-hlsl-pguide.
grammars.trivia: Introduced with DirectX 9; modern compiler `dxc` targets DXIL and SPIR-V—see the https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler.

samples.description: DirectX 12 HelloTriangle shader showing vertex/pixel stages and constant buffers.

grammars.name: HTML
grammars.description: Standard markup language for web documents; current living standard is maintained by WHATWG at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/.
grammars.trivia: Berners-Lee introduced HTML in 1991; the first public description appeared in 1993, and the modern living standard is maintained by WHATWG as the authoritative spec (https://whatwg.org/).

samples.description: Interactive component with inline CSS, JavaScript, templates, and event handlers.

grammars.name: Idris
grammars.description: Dependently typed functional language for verified software; see the official site https://www.idris-lang.org/.
grammars.trivia: Brady introduced Idris in 2009 to bring dependent types to general-purpose programming; the https://www.idris-lang.org/documentation/ demonstrates length-indexed vectors and other proofs in code.

samples.description: Idris2 Data.List module with dependent types, proofs, and list operations.

grammars.name: INI
grammars.description: Simple key-value configuration format; Microsoft documented the `.ini` structure in early Windows SDKs (e.g., https://win16.org/).
grammars.trivia: Windows 1.0 (1985) popularized `.ini` for application settings; the legacy WinAPI functions `GetPrivateProfileString` etc. are still documented in https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/win32/api/winbase/.

samples.description: Combined Python linting config with pycodestyle, flake8, pylint sections and pytest markers.

grammars.name: Java
grammars.description: Object-oriented, class-based language targeting the JVM; authoritative reference is the https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/.
grammars.trivia: Started as 'Oak' then renamed Java after Java coffee; the 'write once, run anywhere' mantra comes from Sun's 1995 launch. The https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/ defines the language across versions.

samples.description: Spring Petclinic domain entity using annotations, collections, comparators.

grammars.name: JavaScript
grammars.description: High-level, dynamic language for the web and beyond; the current language spec is https://tc39.es/ecma262/.
grammars.trivia: Eich created JavaScript in 10 days at Netscape in May 1995; it shipped in Netscape Navigator 2.0. TC39 now standardizes it via https://tc39.es/ecma262/, and the official name of the language is ECMAScript.

samples.description: Alpine.js x-model directive with reactivity, DOM binding, and event handling.

grammars.name: Jinja2
grammars.description: Python templating engine inspired by Django; official docs at https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/.
grammars.trivia: Named after the Jinja shrine; released as part of the Pocoo suite. See the https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/stable/#design-goals and early release history in the docs.

samples.description: Django admin base template with blocks, conditionals, i18n, and component includes.

grammars.name: jq
grammars.description: Command-line JSON processor; manual at the official site https://stedolan.github.io/jq/manual/.
grammars.trivia: jq debuted in 2012 inspired by AWK/sed but for JSON; language features and functions are specified in the https://stedolan.github.io/jq/manual/.

samples.description: Geographic calculations in jq - haversine distance, bearing, coordinate conversions.

grammars.name: JSON
grammars.description: Lightweight data interchange format; see the ECMA-404 standard (https://www.ecma-international.org/publications-and-standards/standards/ecma-404/).
grammars.trivia: Crockford documented JSON in 2001 while at State Software; it was standardized as https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8259 and https://www.ecma-international.org/publications-and-standards/standards/ecma-404/.

samples.description: Vite monorepo package.json with scripts, dependencies, and workspace configuration.

grammars.name: Julia
grammars.description: A high-performance language for numerical and scientific computing with Python-like syntax.
grammars.inventor: Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, Alan Edelman
grammars.trivia: Julia solves the 'two-language problem'—you can prototype in Julia and get C-like speed without rewriting in a lower-level language.

samples.description: Julia's core array implementation with docstrings, macros, and multiple dispatch.

grammars.name: KDL
grammars.description: A document language with XML-like semantics and a more human-friendly syntax.
grammars.trivia: KDL stands for 'KDL Document Language'—the recursive acronym is intentional, inspired by GNU.

samples.description: KDL schema definition with nested nodes and type annotations.

grammars.name: Kotlin
grammars.description: A modern programming language that runs on the JVM, official for Android development
grammars.trivia: Kotlin was named after Kotlin Island near St. Petersburg, Russia, where the JetBrains team is based. Google announced Kotlin as an official Android development language in 2017, and by 2019 made it the preferred language for Android app development.

samples.description: Kotlin standard library sequence operations with lazy evaluation, inline functions, and extension methods.

grammars.name: Lean
grammars.description: Proof assistant and functional language based on dependent type theory; official docs at https://lean-lang.org/.
grammars.trivia: Used to formalize the 2023 Polynomial Freiman–Ruzsa proof by Gowers, Green, Manners, and Tao; the Lean community formalized it in mathlib. mathlib contained over 210,000 theorems as of May 2025 (https://lean-lang.org/blog/2024/05/16/mathlib-200k/); AlphaProof (DeepMind) achieved IMO silver-equivalent performance in 2024 (https://www.deepmind.com/blog/alphaproof-ai-for-mathematical-reasoning).

samples.description: Lean 4 example defining binary trees, recursion, and proofs.

grammars.name: Lua
grammars.description: Lightweight embeddable scripting language from PUC-Rio; official reference manual at https://www.lua.org/manual/5.4/.
grammars.inventor: Roberto Ierusalimschy, Waldemar Celes, Luiz Henrique de Figueiredo
grammars.trivia: Lua (meaning 'moon' in Portuguese) succeeded SOL ('sun'); see the https://www.lua.org/history.html and the 1993 technical report introducing Lua.

samples.description: Lua UTF-8 test exercising pattern matching, loops, and standard library calls.

grammars.name: Markdown
grammars.description: Lightweight markup language for plain-text formatting; original spec on Gruber's site (https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/).
grammars.trivia: Gruber published Markdown 1.0 with Swartz as beta tester in 2004; the canonical description and reference implementation are on https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/.

samples.description: Rust language README with headings, lists, links, images, and code fences.

grammars.name: MATLAB
grammars.description: A numerical computing environment and programming language for matrix operations and data visualization.
grammars.trivia: MATLAB was originally written to give students access to LINPACK and EISPACK without learning Fortran—the name means 'MATrix LABoratory.'

samples.description: FFT signal analysis with functions, plotting, and matrix operations.

grammars.name: Meson
grammars.description: Fast, user-friendly build system using Ninja backend; official docs at https://mesonbuild.com/Manual.html.
grammars.trivia: Pakkanen published Meson in Feb 2013; see the https://nibblestew.blogspot.com/2013/02/introducing-meson-build-system.html and the manual highlighting sub-1s configure times.

samples.description: Real-world Meson build with MSVC/GCC detection, subprojects, and conditional dependencies.

grammars.name: nginx
grammars.description: Configuration language for the nginx web server; official reference at https://nginx.org/en/docs/dirindex.html.
grammars.trivia: Sysoev began nginx in 2002; first public release in 2004. The configuration syntax is documented in the https://nginx.org/en/docs/.

samples.description: H5BP nginx.conf with includes, gzip, SSL, maps, and logging directives.

grammars.name: Ninja
grammars.description: A small, fast build system focused on speed, designed as a backend for higher-level build systems.
grammars.trivia: Ninja was created at Google to speed up Chrome builds—it's intentionally minimal and meant to be generated by tools like CMake or Meson.

samples.description: Ninja build file with rules, variables, and build edges for C++.

grammars.name: Nix
grammars.description: Purely functional package manager and language for reproducible builds; see Dolstra's PhD thesis https://edolstra.github.io/pubs/phd-thesis.pdf.
grammars.trivia: Nix stores packages in hash-addressed store paths (e.g., /nix/store/...), eliminating dependency hell. The design is formalized in Dolstra's 2006 thesis and underpins NixOS.

samples.description: crane helper derivation that builds dependencies only, showing functions, let bindings, overrides, and mkDerivation usage.

grammars.name: Objective-C
grammars.description: Object-oriented superset of C used for macOS/iOS; Apple's modern reference is the https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/ProgrammingWithObjectiveC/.
grammars.trivia: Derived from Smalltalk messaging added to C; NeXT licensed it in 1988, leading to its adoption by Apple after 1996—documented in Apple's developer library.

samples.description: React Native logging utility showing categories, macros, Objective-C classes, and C functions.

grammars.name: OCaml
grammars.description: A multi-paradigm programming language with emphasis on expressiveness and safety
grammars.inventor: Xavier Leroy, Jérôme Vouillon, Damien Doligez, Didier Rémy
grammars.trivia: The 'O' in OCaml stands for 'Objective', as it was called Objective Caml before 2011. OCaml is used extensively in formal verification and financial trading systems. Jane Street, one of the largest proprietary trading firms, uses OCaml for over 30 million lines of production code.

samples.description: OCaml standard library option type with pattern matching, monadic operations, and syntax extensions.

grammars.name: Perl
grammars.description: General-purpose scripting language renowned for text processing; core docs at https://perldoc.perl.org/.
grammars.trivia: Wall released Perl 1.0 on 18 Dec 1987; the motto 'There's more than one way to do it' is from the official https://perldoc.perl.org/perlstyle and https://perldoc.perl.org/perlintro documentation.

samples.description: Perl5 Time::gmtime module with exports, OO wrappers, and POD documentation.

grammars.name: PHP
grammars.description: Server-side scripting language; the official manual is at https://www.php.net/manual/en/.
grammars.trivia: Started as 'Personal Home Page Tools' in 1994/95; renamed 'PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor' in 1997. History is documented in the https://www.php.net/ChangeLog-8.php and manual preface.

samples.description: Laravel SessionGuard with authentication, traits, and typed properties.

grammars.name: PostScript
grammars.description: Page description and programming language from Adobe; reference in the https://www.adobe.com/content/dam/acom/en/devnet/actionscript/articles/PLRM.pdf.
grammars.trivia: Adobe released PostScript in 1984; the LaserWriter (1985) used it to ignite desktop publishing. The 'Red Book' PLRM is the definitive spec.

samples.description: Ghostscript tiger example showcasing PostScript drawing, paths, fills, and strokes.

grammars.name: PowerShell
grammars.description: Task automation shell and scripting language; official docs at https://learn.microsoft.com/powershell/.
grammars.trivia: Born from Snover's 2002 'Monad Manifesto'; first released 2006. Open-sourced and cross-platform in 2016 as PowerShell Core—see the https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell.

samples.description: PowerShell test script exercising cmdlets, parameter sets, error handling, and assertions.

grammars.name: Prolog
grammars.description: Logic programming language for AI and computational linguistics; early definition in Colmerauer's 1972 Marseille reports.
grammars.trivia: Prolog (PROgrammation en LOGique) emerged in 1972; used in Japan's Fifth Generation Project (1982). The ISO standard is https://www.iso.org/standard/21413.html.

samples.description: SWI-Prolog HTTP server example with predicates, handlers, and threading.

grammars.name: Python
grammars.description: High-level general-purpose language emphasizing readability; authoritative reference is the https://docs.python.org/3/reference/.
grammars.trivia: Named after Monty Python; van Rossum released Python 0.9.0 in Feb 1991. The 'Zen of Python' is documented in `import this` and the https://peps.python.org/pep-0020/.

samples.description: Rich demo showing dynamic progress bars, context managers, multiple progress tasks.

grammars.name: Tree-sitter Query
grammars.description: A S-expression based pattern language for matching nodes in tree-sitter syntax trees.
grammars.trivia: Tree-sitter queries power syntax highlighting in editors like Neovim, Helix, and Zed—this is what arborium uses under the hood.

samples.description: Tree-sitter highlight queries with S-expressions and captures.

grammars.name: R
grammars.description: Language and environment for statistical computing; official manuals at https://cran.r-project.org/manuals.html.
grammars.trivia: Named for Ross and Robert and as a successor to S; initial public release was 1995. The https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-lang.html documents core semantics.

samples.description: stringr functions for detecting patterns; showcases vectorization and tidyverse style.

grammars.name: ReScript
grammars.description: Functional language that compiles to JavaScript, evolved from BuckleScript/Reason; docs at https://rescript-lang.org/docs/latest.
grammars.inventor: Hongbo Zhang and the ReScript team
grammars.trivia: Rebranded from BuckleScript/Reason in 2020 to focus on a JS-centric pipeline; see the https://rescript-lang.org/blog/announcement and docs for the syntax and compiler.

samples.description: ReScript Core array module with external bindings, recursive functions, and comparisons.

grammars.name: RON
grammars.description: Rusty Object Notation, a Rust-friendly data format; reference at https://docs.rs/ron/latest/ron/.
grammars.trivia: Designed for a (canceled) game project and revived by the Rust community; features trailing commas, comments, and Rust-like enums—see the crate docs on https://docs.rs/ron.

samples.description: Veloren game server kit definitions with nested item tuples, comments, and RON extensions.

grammars.name: Ruby
grammars.description: A dynamic, object-oriented language designed for programmer happiness and productivity.
grammars.trivia: Matz (Yukihiro Matsumoto) chose the name Ruby as a playful reference to Perl—ruby is a precious stone, like pearl.

samples.description: Rails ActiveSupport inflector with pluralize, singularize, and camelize methods.

grammars.name: Rust
grammars.description: Systems language focused on safety and performance without GC; official docs at https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/.
grammars.trivia: Hoare began Rust as a side project at Mozilla in 2006; it became a Mozilla-backed project in 2009. The ownership/borrow checker model is documented in the https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ch04-00-understanding-ownership.html.

samples.description: Clippy lint implementation with trait checking, generic handling, and diagnostics.

grammars.name: Scala
grammars.description: Multi-paradigm JVM language blending OO and FP; official docs at https://docs.scala-lang.org/.
grammars.trivia: The name abbreviates 'scalable language'; Odersky announced Scala in 2004 after work on Java generics and the Pizza language. The https://docs.scala-lang.org/scala3/reference/ documents current syntax and features.

samples.description: Sangria GraphQL result resolver with pattern matching, options, and marshallers.

grammars.name: Scheme
grammars.description: A minimalist dialect of Lisp with lexical scope, first-class procedures, and tail-call optimization
grammars.inventor: Guy L. Steele Jr., Gerald Jay Sussman
grammars.trivia: Scheme was created at MIT AI Lab and influenced the design of many languages including JavaScript (which borrowed first-class functions and closures). The language was intentionally small - the original spec fit on 50 pages. Scheme's name comes from 'Schemer', after the AI language Planner, but was shortened due to filename length limits.

samples.description: Racket list utilities with macros, recursive functions, tail-call optimization, and comprehensive error handling.

grammars.name: SCSS
grammars.description: Sass/SCSS is a CSS superset adding variables, nesting, and mixins; see the official https://sass-lang.com/documentation/.
grammars.inventor: Hampton Catlin, Natalie Weizenbaum, Chris Eppstein
grammars.trivia: SCSS syntax arrived with Sass 3 (2010) to mirror CSS; history and design notes are in the https://sass-lang.com/blog/ and https://sass-lang.com/documentation/syntax.

samples.description: Bootstrap buttons partial with variables, mixins, nesting, and interpolation.

grammars.name: SPARQL
grammars.description: A query language for retrieving and manipulating data stored in RDF (Resource Description Framework) format.
grammars.inventor: W3C RDF Data Access Working Group
grammars.trivia: SPARQL is a recursive acronym: 'SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language'—it powers knowledge graphs like Wikidata and DBpedia.

samples.description: SPARQL queries with SELECT, CONSTRUCT, FILTER, and aggregations.

grammars.name: SQL
grammars.description: Structured Query Language for relational databases; standardized by ANSI/ISO, see https://www.iso.org/standard/63555.html (paywalled) and https://sqlite.org/lang.html as an open reference.
grammars.inventor: Donald D. Chamberlin and Raymond F. Boyce
grammars.trivia: Initially called SEQUEL at IBM for System R; trademark issues shortened it to SQL. Early history is recounted in Chamberlin's paper 'SEQUEL: A Structured English Query Language'.

samples.description: PostgreSQL regression test covering joins, lateral, outer joins, aggregates, and set operations.

grammars.name: SSH Config
grammars.description: Configuration file format for OpenSSH client settings like hosts, keys, and connection options.
grammars.trivia: SSH was created in 1995 after a password-sniffing attack at Helsinki University of Technology prompted Tatu Ylönen to develop a secure replacement for rlogin.

samples.description: SSH client configuration with hosts, identity files, and forwarding.

grammars.name: Starlark
grammars.description: Deterministic, hermetic build language used by Bazel/Buck2; spec at https://bazel.build/rules/language.
grammars.trivia: Originally named Skylark (2015), renamed Starlark in 2018; deterministic semantics documented in the https://bazel.build/rules/language.

samples.description: Bazel repository rule definitions using load, attrs, functions, and repository_ctx.

grammars.name: Svelte
grammars.description: Compiler-based UI framework that outputs minimal JS; official tutorial at https://svelte.dev/docs/introduction.
grammars.trivia: Harris announced Svelte in 2016 to eliminate the virtual DOM; the https://svelte.dev/blog covers milestones like SvelteKit and run-time improvements.

samples.description: Svelte starter component with props, scoped styles, and reactive declarations.

grammars.name: Swift
grammars.description: A powerful and intuitive programming language for Apple platforms
grammars.trivia: Chris Lattner started Swift as a personal project in 2010 while working at Apple, spending 18 months on it before getting approval to make it official. He also created LLVM and Clang. Swift was designed to be a safer language than Objective-C, eliminating entire categories of bugs through features like optionals and automatic memory management.

samples.description: Vapor directory configuration with platform-specific imports, working directory detection, and string extensions.

grammars.name: Text Proto
grammars.description: A human-readable text format for Protocol Buffer messages, commonly used for configuration files.
grammars.trivia: Protocol Buffers were developed at Google in 2001 and are used for nearly all inter-machine communication at the company.

samples.description: Protocol Buffer text format with nested messages and repeated fields.

grammars.name: Thrift
grammars.description: Interface Definition Language and RPC framework; official Apache docs at https://thrift.apache.org/docs.
grammars.trivia: Developed at Facebook starting 2006, open-sourced 2007; entered Apache Incubator in 2008 and became a TLP in 2010—see the https://thrift.apache.org/.

samples.description: Official Apache Thrift tutorial showing services, structs, enums, and exceptions.

grammars.name: TLA+
grammars.description: Temporal Logic of Actions (TLA+) for formal specs; the canonical reference is Lamport's book https://lamport.azurewebsites.net/tla/book.html.
grammars.trivia: Lamport introduced TLA+ in the late 1990s; AWS famously uses it to find subtle bugs—see Lamport's papers and the TLA+ hyperbook.

samples.description: Paxos consensus algorithm specification with message-passing, quorums, and ballot phases.

grammars.name: TOML
grammars.description: Tom's Obvious, Minimal Language for configuration; official spec at https://toml.io/en/.
grammars.trivia: TOML 1.0.0 was released January 2021 after 8 years of iteration; see the spec changelog on https://toml.io/en/v1.0.0.

samples.description: Starship Cargo.toml with dependencies, features, and build configuration.

grammars.name: TSX
grammars.description: TypeScript with JSX support for React component development
grammars.trivia: TSX combines TypeScript's static type checking with JSX's declarative UI syntax. While JSX was introduced by Facebook for React in 2013, TSX emerged as TypeScript gained popularity and React developers sought better tooling. Today, TSX is the de facto standard for React development in TypeScript codebases.

samples.description: TanStack Query basic example with data fetching, caching, custom hooks, and React components.

grammars.name: TypeScript
grammars.description: Statically typed superset of JavaScript; official handbook at https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/.
grammars.trivia: Announced by Microsoft in Oct 2012 to add optional types to JS; design is documented in the TypeScript spec and Handbook.

samples.description: DOT printer for function graphs with generics, async IO, and string templating.

grammars.name: Typst
grammars.description: A modern markup-based typesetting system designed as a faster, friendlier alternative to LaTeX.
grammars.trivia: Typst compiles documents incrementally—changes preview instantly, unlike LaTeX which must recompile the entire document.

samples.description: Polylux presentation theme with slide layouts; showcases Typst's page styling, state management, and function definitions.

grammars.name: Uiua
grammars.description: A stack-based array programming language with a focus on tacit (point-free) code using Unicode glyphs.
grammars.trivia: Uiua (pronounced 'wee-wuh') uses Unicode symbols for operations—you can type them with ASCII shortcuts that auto-convert.

samples.description: Uiua array language with stack-based operations and unicode glyphs.

grammars.name: Visual Basic
grammars.description: Visual Basic .NET, object-oriented language for the .NET Framework; language reference at https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/visual-basic/.
grammars.trivia: Launched with .NET Framework 1.0 in 2002 as a rewrite of VB6; the https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/visual-basic/language-reference/ documents syntax changes and OO features.

samples.description: Roslyn VB.NET operation factory with Select Case, DirectCast, and compiler internals.

grammars.name: Verilog
grammars.description: Hardware description language standardized as https://standards.ieee.org/ieee/1364/2985/.
grammars.trivia: Created at Gateway Design Automation (later Cadence) in 1984; became an open IEEE standard in 1995 (IEEE 1364-1995).

samples.description: CVA6 RISC-V ALU module with parameters, always_comb, generate blocks, and bit manipulation.
BE-P decoder state machine with always blocks, parameters, and nonblocking assignments.

grammars.name: VHDL
grammars.description: VHSIC Hardware Description Language; standardized as https://standards.ieee.org/ieee/1076/7424/.
grammars.trivia: Developed under the VHSIC program and standardized in 1987 as IEEE 1076; later revisions added numeric_std and child standards.

samples.description: GHDL finite state machine test with entity, architecture, process, and case statement.

grammars.name: Vimscript
grammars.description: Scripting language for the Vim editor; see the official Vim documentation at http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/.
grammars.trivia: Vimscript evolved alongside Vim since 1991; Vim 7 (2006) added major scripting features. Bram maintained Vim until his passing in 2023.

samples.description: Vim plugin with functions, autocommands, mappings, and conditionals.

grammars.name: Vue
grammars.description: Progressive JavaScript framework for UIs; official docs at https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html.
grammars.trivia: You released Vue in Feb 2014 after working on Angular at Google; the https://github.com/vuejs/core/releases and guide document its evolution from 0.10 to Vue 3/4 composition API.

samples.description: Element Plus Button component with Vue 3 Composition API, TypeScript, and dynamic styling.

grammars.name: x86 Assembly
grammars.description: Assembly language family for Intel x86; reference manuals at https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/developer/articles/technical/intel-sdm.html.
grammars.trivia: Built on the 8086 ISA released June 1978; Intel's Software Developer Manuals document backward compatibility that lets 1978-era code run on modern CPUs.

samples.description: NASM ELF test exercising labels, externs, sections, and symbol definitions.

grammars.name: XML
grammars.description: Extensible Markup Language defined by the W3C XML 1.0 Recommendation.
grammars.trivia: Work began in 1996; XML 1.0 became a W3C Recommendation on Feb 10, 1998, led by Bray, Paoli, and Sperberg-McQueen.

samples.description: Spring Petclinic Maven POM with dependencies, plugins, profiles, and properties.

grammars.name: YAML
grammars.description: Human-friendly data serialization language; official 1.2 spec at https://yaml.org/spec/1.2.2/.
grammars.inventor: Clark Evans, Ingy döt Net, Oren Ben-Kiki
grammars.trivia: Originally 'Yet Another Markup Language', later 'YAML Ain't Markup Language'; first proposed in 2001—see the https://yaml.org/spec/history/2001-01.html.

samples.description: Istio Bookinfo sample with Services, ServiceAccounts, and Deployments for microservices.

grammars.name: Yuri
grammars.description: Yuri shader language; see repository README for current design status.
grammars.trivia: Yuri is an in-progress shader language and compiler; the design is not finalized and is released under Apache-2.0.

samples.description: Example Yuri shader demonstrating language syntax.

grammars.name: Zig
grammars.description: General-purpose systems language focused on simplicity and control; docs at https://ziglang.org/documentation/master/.
grammars.trivia: Kelley introduced Zig in 2016 as a C replacement without hidden control flow; the self-hosted compiler milestone is chronicled on the https://ziglang.org/news/.

samples.description: Args-lex generic tokenizer with slices, enums, error sets, and comptime parsing.

grammars.name: Zsh
grammars.description: Extended Unix shell with rich scripting; reference manual at https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/.
grammars.trivia: Created by Falstad while at Princeton; named after TA Zhong Shao. The https://zsh.sourceforge.io/FAQ/ documents its history and feature set.

samples.description: oh-my-zsh git plugin with aliases, functions, and completions.
